all_paragraphs: By Mehdi Ben Ayed and Patrick Halina from Zynga’s ML Engineering Team

Designing user experiences is a difficult art. Compared to other applications, video games provide designers a huge canvas to work with. At Zynga, we’re constantly thinking of innovative ways to maximize our user’s experience while playing our games.

In this multi-part series, Zynga’s ML Engineering Team will discuss how deep reinforcement learning (RL) is used in production to personalize many aspects of Zynga’s games. The use of deep reinforcement learning has proven to be successful at increasing key metrics such as user retention and user engagement. These articles are an extension of our presentations at the Toronto Machine Learning Summit 2019 and Spark Summit 2020.

Zynga is one of the leading developers of mobile games in the world. Its portfolio has some of the world’s most popular mobile games, like Words with Friends, Empires and Puzzles, Toon Blast, CSR2, Poker, and many more. Zynga’s mission is to connect people from everywhere in the world through games.

Building successful applications for a wide range of users is challenging. How difficult should the daily challenge be? What game mode should we recommend? Each user is different, which makes it difficult to build an application that fits everyone’s needs. The difference can be due to the player’s demographics, location, or even their style of play. As a result, building personalized user experiences has the potential to increase user engagement and retention.

While there are many knobs and levers to control during a user’s session, personalization can be boiled down to a common pattern: given a user’s state, select an action in order to maximize a long term reward.

Zynga has a long history of using personalization to enhance the game experience. One simple method that has been used with a lot of success is rule-based optimization. This approach splits players into segments (or groups) based on the player’s attributes and delivers a custom experience for each of those segments.

The rise of deep learning and its combination with reinforcement learning (RL) in recent years offers a new solution to personalization.

Deep learning is a type of machine learning that uses artificial neural networks to learn complex relationships in data. Given a large set of data and expected output, the neural network is trained to learn the pattern that transforms the input data to the expected output.

The layered architecture of these networks, in addition to the use of activation functions, allows these models to learn both lower and higher-level concepts in data, which is not possible using classical machine learning models.

Deep learning experienced a high number of breakthroughs in recent years which led to a phenomenal number of successes in the fields, such as image and speech recognition and deep reinforcement learning.

Reinforcement learning, on the other hand, is a classical machine learning technique. It focuses on training agents to make sequences of decisions that maximize the total reward over the long term. The long term aspect is key; agents do not select actions to optimize for the short term. Agents are able to incur a loss in the short term to receive a larger gain at a later point in time.

Agents trained using deep reinforcement learning not only learn optimal strategies to solve complex problems, but also adapt to changes in the environment over time.

Deep learning and deep reinforcement learning unlocked the power to solve problems that were not possible before, such as planning in a complex environment and learning patterns in high dimensional space. At Zynga, we believe that the use of deep reinforcement learning will continue to enable us to personalize our games to every user no matter their skill level, location, or demographic.

In the next articles, we will share with you more information about the different use cases deep reinforcement learning agents are used in order to personalize our users’ experience. We will also provide insights into our machine learning infrastructure and the deep reinforcement learning framework that we built and open-sourced called rl-bakery. Finally, we will share some of the main challenges and learnings we made during this process.
